Lavrentieva, 5 Novosibirsk 630090 Russian Federation Graphical abstract The present work is devoted to the study of doping effects of zinc, gallium and silver on the structure of active sites and catalytic properties of carbon-supported 0.5 wt% Pd catalysts in the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. Carbonaceous graphite-like material Sibunit was used as a support. The reaction was performed in a medium of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone at 55 °C. It was shown that the bimetallic Pd-Zn/C, Pd-Ga/C and Pd-Ag/C catalysts exhibit better activity and selectivity towards target product if compare with the monometallic Pd/C catalyst. The ethylene yield increases in a row as follows: Pd/C (19%) < Pd-Ag/C (34%) < Pd-Ga/C (42%) < Pd-Zn/C (53%). Using X-ray absorption spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy it was found that an improvement of the selectivity is stipulated by the formation of bimetallic PdZn, PdxGay and PdAg nanophases. In the case of Pd-Zn/C and Pd-Ag/C systems, an increased distance between neighboring Pd atoms (2.82–2.89 Å) in relation with monometallic Pd/C, where this distance is 2.72 Å, was observed. The higher activity of modified bimetallic systems is connected with increased number of active sites due to enhanced dispersity of supported palladium doped with second metal. Keywords Liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene Palladium catalyst Bimetallic catalysts Metal-metal interaction Carbonaceous support 1 Introduction Nowadays, palladium supported on different carriers is one of the most intensively studied catalytic systems. Pd-based catalysts exhibit excellent activity in such important from practical point of view processes as hydrogenation of organic acids and oils [1,2] and halogen-substituted organic compounds [3,4], selective hydrogenation of polyunsaturated compounds [5] and acetylene [6–12], reduction of aromatic nitrocompounds [13], oxidation of methane [14–16] and carbon monoxide [17–20], etc. At the same time, a tendency towards using the bimetallic [21–29] or even trimetallic [30] systems instead of Pd-only catalysts has to be stated. Doping the Pd-based catalysts with second metal creates a new type of active sites consisting of palladium and modifying metal atoms. As a rule, such sites facilitate an improvement of the process selectivity thus increasing the yield of the target product. In the case of bimetallic catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene, a key role is considered to be played by a dilution of Pd atoms with atoms of modifying metal within the structure of the nanophases being formed. This leads to an increase of the distance between neighboring atoms of palladium from 2.75 Å for metallic Pd to approximately 2.82–2.99 Å depending on the applied modifier [27,31–33]. Such structure of the active sites practically rules out the possibility for strong multisite adsorption of acetylene and, thereby, prevents the realization of secondary reactions such as the hydrogenation of ethylene to ethane and formation of C4+ oligomers [21,32]. At the same time, a contribution of electron interaction of Pd with modifier is of significant importance. Atoms of second metal act as donors of electron density for vacant d-orbitals of palladium that suppresses an affinity of Pd towards adsorption of unsaturated compounds, facilitates desorption of ethylene and impedes its complete hydrogenation to ethane [21,34]. Among the promising catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene, Pd-containing catalytic systems doped with silver, gold, zinc, gallium, indium, copper and manganese should be mentioned [21,22,34]. These catalysts were reported to be efficient as for industrial gas-phase purification of ethylene from acetylene traces, as for hydrogenation of relatively large amounts of C2H2 (above 4 vol.%). For example, the latter process is used in an experimental technology patented by Synfuels International Inc., where acetylene obtained via pyrolysis of natural and associated oil gases is subjected to hydrogenation procedure in order to produce marketable ethylene and/or high-octane components of engine fuels [35,36]. Because the process is strongly exothermic (ΔH = 174.5 kJ/mol), this requires to be performed in a solvent medium for the safety reasons. This approach allows one not only removing the reaction heat but facilitates an improvement in selectivity towards ethylene. On the other hand, a description in the literature of the bimetallic catalysts applied for the considered process is limited by the mentioned patents [35,36]. Thereby, a detailed research in this field attracts both the fundamental and practical interests. Recently we have already reported about carbon-supported Pd-Ga catalysts for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene [6,37–39]. Porous carbonaceous material Sibunit was used as a support, which choice was stipulated, first of all, by absence of strong surface acid sites responsible for oligomerization of acetylene [40,41]. Moreover, carbon materials are more preferable than oxide supports (for instance, Al2O3) because in the case of the latter a part of modifier’s atoms can be lost due to their incorporation into the support bulk with formation of solid solutions [42]. Carbon materials, in their turn, were reported to show a weak or even negligible metal-support interaction [43]. It is obvious that elimination of the negative metal-support interaction should intensify the efficiency of Pd-M interaction (where M is second metal) resulting in the formation of more active and selective bimetallic phases [38]. As it was shown for Pd-Ga/C catalysts, an increase of selectivity (on about 20 rel.%) in relation to the monometallic Pd/C catalyst is connected with the presence of alloyed Pd-Ga particles being formed during the catalyst preparation at the stage of its reductive treatment in a hydrogen flow [6,44]. Possibility in principle for the formation of Pd-Zn and Pd-Ag bimetallic systems characterized with enhanced selectivity in the hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene was described elsewhere [44]. In the present research, the structural features of carbon-supported bimetallic Pd-Ag, Pd-Zn and Pd-Ga catalysts prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation of Sibunit with solutions of corresponding nitrates are studied in detail. A special attention was paid to intercommunication between the data of transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray absorption spectroscopy and the catalytic performance of the samples in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts In the present study, porous carbonaceous material Sibunit (fraction of 0.07–0.09 mm) with a specific surface area of 335 m2/g was used as a support [45]. It should be noted that Sibunit is able to reduce palladium in the solution of its salts with formation of a particulate palladium black. In order to prevent this undesired process, the support was preliminary treated with a 5% solution of nitric acid with subsequent evaporation of the latter on a water bath. Then, the support was dried on air. Such treatment leads to formation of the oxygen-containing functional groups (carboxyl, lactonic and phenolic) on the surface [46], which presence increases the affinity of the carbon support to interaction with the precursors of the active component. The supported bimetallic catalysts were prepared via an incipient wetness impregnation of the pretreated support with joint aqueous solution of nitrates of corresponding metals (Pd(NO3)2 and Ga(NO3)3, Zn(NO3)2 or AgNO3). The solution was added dropwise to the support’s sample at intensive stirring. It should be noted that this preparation technique differs from that previously used for obtaining the similar catalysts [44], when the sample of the support was added to a constant volume of the joint solution and thoroughly stirred until the formation of slurry. The obtained samples were dried on air at 120 °C for 2 h. The only exception was Pd-Ag/C sample, which was dried in complete darkness at room temperature for 24 h. Then, the samples were reduced in a hydrogen flow (with a flow rate of 60 ml/min) at 500 °C for 5 h. Finally, the palladium loading was 0.5 wt%, and molar ratio Pd:M was 1:1. The reference monometallic Pd/C sample containing 0.5 wt% of palladium was prepared in the similar way. 2.2 Testing the catalytic performance Catalytic properties of the samples were studied in a non-gradient temperature-controlled shaker-type flow reactor at 55 °C and atmospheric pressure as described elsewhere [40]. The sample of the catalyst (20 mg) was loaded into the reactor along with 8.0 ml of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, which was used as a solvent characterized with a high capacity towards acetylene and worse solubility towards ethylene and other reaction products [47]. Then, the reactor was fed with a reaction gas mixture containing 4 vol.% C2H2 and 96 vol.% H2 with a flow rate of 100 ml/min. The reaction was performed under intensive shaking of the catalytic reactor with a frequency of 7–8 s−1. The duration of the catalytic test was 220 min that allows determining the activity under steady state conditions. The reaction mixture on the inlet and outlet of the reactor was analyzed using a Chromos GC-1000 gas chromatograph equipped with a capillary column (stationary phase SiO2) and a flame ionization detector. Nitrogen was used as a carrier gas. The catalytic parameters (conversion of acetylene, XC2H2, %; selectivity towards ethylene, SC2H4, %, and ethane, SC2H6, %) were calculated by the normalization method. The selectivity towards oligomers was obtained as follows: SC4+ = 100% - (SC2H4 + SC2H6). The yield of ethylene (YC2H4, %) was calculated as a product of acetylene conversion and ethylene selectivity (YC2H4= XC2H2× SC2H4). The blank catalytic tests carried out for bare Sibunit and Sibunit-supported zinc, gallium and silver (0.3-0.5 wt%) samples have revealed an inertness of these materials in the reaction under study. 2.3 Characterization of the samples Transmission electron microscopic studies of the samples were performed using a JEOL JEM 2100 microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV and resolution of 0.14 nm. During the pretreatment procedure, the samples were grinded in an agate mortar for 30 s, the obtained powder was mixed with ethanol and dispersed using an ultrasonic equipment (UZDN-2T, Russia). The resulted suspension was deposited on a carbon support fixed on a copper grid. Gold monocrystals with corresponding Miller indexes (111) and interatomic distance of 0.235 nm were used as a reference. The TEM data were used to estimate the average particle size of the supported metals and their particle size distributions. Chemical analysis was carried out using an INCA-250 X-ray energy dispersive spectrometer (Oxford Instruments) with a Si(Li)-detector provided resolution of 130 eV. The chemical state and structure of local environment of Pd, Zn, Ga and Ag atoms were studied by X-ray Absorption Near Edge Structure (XANES) and Extended X-Ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) spectroscopies. The XAS measurements were carried out at the “Structural Materials Science” beamline at the Kurchatov synchrotron radiation source (SRC “Kurchatov Institute”, Moscow). The energy of electron beam in the storage ring was 2.5 GeV. Monochromation of the synchrotron radiation was performed using a silicon channel-cut single crystal Si(311) for Pd and Ag K-edge spectra at an energy resolution of ΔE/E = 1 × 10−4, and Si(111) for Zn and Ga K-edge spectraat ΔE/E = 2 × 10−4 in the form of monoblock with a cutaway “Butterfly” installed on a goniometer head. All the spectra were measured in a “transmission” geometry using two ionization chambers filled with Ar and connected to Keithley 6487 picoamperemeters. X-ray absorption of palladium foil (reference) was measured simultaneously with the samples using the third ionization chamber. Processing of the experimental spectra was done using the software packages ATHENA and ARTEMIS [48]. The absorption edge energy E0 was calibrated in relation to value of the first maximum on the K-edge first derivative (first inflection point energy). In the case of metallic palladium (Pd foil), this maximum corresponds to 1s→5p dipole transition at 24,350.3 eV. Ag, Ga and Zn K-edge absorption edge energies are 25,514, 10,367 and 9,659 eV, respectively [49]. The model EXAFS spectra for the studied samples were constructed using the data taken from Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD) [50]. The amplitudes and photoelectron scattering phases were computed using the FEFF6 program [51]. Normalized EXAFS oscillations were k3 -weighted and analyzed in a 2.0–12.0 Å−1 k-range. Modelling of the EXAFS spectra was performed in the R-space. The model includes single-scattering paths on a distance till 4.0 Å. Spectra for bulk metallic palladium and gallium (foils) were obtained under the same conditions. Reference data for Ga2O3, Zn and ZnO were taken from the database [52]. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalytic performance of the carbon-supported palladium catalysts The results of catalytic tests of the bimetallic Pd-Zn/C, Pd-Ga/C and Pd-Ag/C catalysts as well as the reference monometallic Pd/C sample are presented in Table 1 . It is obvious that the modifying effect is significantly determined by the nature of the modifier used. All the doped catalysts are more active than the reference Pd/C catalyst. Thus, an introduction of silver increases the acetylene conversion in 1.4 times, while doping with gallium or zinc has led to more significant growth of the conversion: in 2.1 and 2.5 times, respectively. It should be mentioned that an improvement of the activity of supported palladium in the acetylene hydrogenation is not character for the silver-doped samples [27,28,32,53,54]. As a rule, the formation of PdAg nanoalloys is accompanied with redistribution of electron density. Silver being electronegative element serves as a donor of electrons and gives them to the vacant d-orbitals of palladium. This diminishes sharply receptivity of Pd to the adsorption of unsaturated compounds and, accordingly, worsens the activity in hydrogenation [21,34]. Analogous effects in the case of studied Pd-Ag/C system are not excluded. The observable growth of C2H2 conversion for the Ag-doped catalyst can be facilitated by other factors. For example, it is well known that the activity can be noticeably affected by the dispersity of the supported active component [55,56], which, in its turn, depends on the catalyst’s composition and the way of its preparation [57,58]. It is evident that an increase in activity of the Pd-Ag/C, Pd-Ga/C and Pd-Zn/C catalysts in relation to the reference Pd/C catalyst indicates that both the nature and the amount of the active sites have changed under the action of introduced modifiers. On the other hand, the Pd-Ag/C catalyst exhibits the highest selectivity in the hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. The value of selectivity obtained for this catalyst exceeds that for the reference sample on 20 rel.%. Suppression of the side reactions of ethane formation and hydro-oligomerization of acetylene, which products are C4+ hydrocarbons (butane and butenes), results in a slight increase of the ethylene yield. Doping the palladium catalyst with Zn also enhances the selectivity on 15 rel.% with regard to the reference sample. High enough values of acetylene conversion and selectivity towards ethylene for this sample provide the highest yield of the target product (53%) that is almost in 3 times higher if compare with the unmodified Pd/C catalyst. In the case of the Ga-doped catalyst, the selectivity increase is not so sufficient. The product distribution for this system is very similar to that for the monometallic reference sample. However, improved acetylene conversion over this sample results in more than 2 times higher ethylene yield (42%). In general, in relation to the values of ethylene yield in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene the samples can be ranked as follows: Pd-Zn/C > Pd-Ga/C > Pd-Ag/C > Pd/C. As it is suggested in the literature [6,23,43,59,60], the formation of bimetallic Pd-Zn, Pd-Ga and Pd-Ag structures is responsible for an increase of selectivity towards ethylene. It is well known that thermal treatment of the Pd-Zn catalysts in a reductive medium leads to formation of tetragonal β1-PdZn phase of equimolar composition [33,61]. In the case of Pd-Ga systems, such intermetallic nanostructures as Pd2Ga, PdGa5, PdGa, Pd3Ga7, etc. could be formed [62–64]. Alloying of palladium with silver results in appearance of bimetallic alloyed nanoparticles, which composition depends on the initially chosen ratio of metals [29,60]. The main feature of the mentioned bimetallic compounds is seemed to be in an efficient isolation of neighboring Pd atoms via their “dilution” with atoms of the modifying element [60,65,66]. The being formed Pd-Zn-Pd, Pd-Ga-Pd and Pd-Ag-Pd ensembles exhibit higher selectivity towards incomplete hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds. For such structures, adsorption of acetylene in a di-σ-bonded configuration (which is an intermediate of the total hydrogenation to ethane) over two neighboring Pd atoms is practically prevented. Thereby, acetylene adsorbed as a π-complex (which leads to ethylene formation) over a single Pd atom becomes the dominating intermediate. It should be emphasized that the π-form of acetylene adsorption is weaker that makes the process of target product desorption easier [60]. Moreover, the modification of Pd catalysts changes significantly the adsorption characteristics of the catalyst surface. In particular, according to Ref. [66], the heat of acetylene adsorption diminishes from 235 kJ/mol for Pd/Al2O3 catalysts to 203 kJ/mol for PdZn (active species of Pd/ZnO). For ethylene, the adsorption heat drops down from 169 to 90 kJ/mol. It should be noted once again that the difference in results of the catalytic tests presented in the given work and reported earlier [44] deals more with the preparation routes used to obtain the samples. It is well known that formation of the active sites of the supported metallic catalysts is quite sensitive for the synthesis procedures [58]. In particular, both the order and the rate of the mixing of the support with solutions of salt-precursors can significantly affect the dispersity of the active component particles being formed. Moreover, in the case of modified samples, character of Pd atoms interaction with atoms of modifiers should also differ that, in its turn, should make an influence on the catalytic performance [58]. In order to enhance additionally such kind of interaction between palladium and modifiers, the duration of the thermal treatment procedure in a hydrogen flow was increased from 3 to 5 h. Thereby, the changes in catalytic performance of the bimetallic Pd-Zn/C, Pd-Ga/C and Pd-Ag/C samples as well as the reference Pd/C sample were studied with regard to the state and structure of the active components using transmission electron microscopy and X-ray absorption spectroscopy. 3.2 TEM studies of the samples TEM images of the bimetallic Pd-Zn/C, Pd-Ga/C, Pd-Ag/C catalysts and the monometallic Pd/C catalyst are shown in Fig. 1 . In all the images, spherical particles of Sibunit associated into agglomerates of 50–150 nm in size are well seen. The supported active components are represented by globular-shaped nanoparticles uniformly distributed over the Sibunit surface. Phase composition of mono- and bimetallic nanoparticles was estimated by measuring the values of interplanar spaces d. The calculations were performed by analysis of the electron-diffraction patterns obtained after the Fourier transformations of the nanoparticle’s crystal lattice images. It was found that all the catalysts contain nanoparticles with interplanar spaces d = 0.225 nm, which are characteristic of metallic palladium. In the cases of the bimetallic systems, nanoparticles with spaces of 0.219 nm (Pd-Zn/C and Pd-Ga/C), 0.228 and 0.236 nm (Pd-Ag/C) are detected. These values can be assigned to the interplanar spaces for PdZn(011) (PDF 06-0620), Pd2Ga(211) (COD 8102983), PdAg(111) [67,68] and metallic Ag (ICSD 52257) [68]. Local energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) of the monometallic Pd/C catalyst gave the following content of the elements: carbon is near 98 at.%; oxygen is 0.5–1 at.%; palladium is 0.5–1 at.%; silicon is less than 0.5 at.%. It should be noted that silicon is one of the ash-forming impurities within composition of Sibunit, and its presence in the catalysts is quite expected. Oxygen is presented in the support in the form of oxygen-containing functional groups appeared as a result of its oxidative treatment with nitric acid. Along with it, a part of the supported metal can be in an oxidative state. Elemental composition of the bimetallic samples, excluding element-modifier, is similar to that for the reference Pd/C catalyst. These catalysts contain nanoparticles of metallic palladium along with alloyed nanoparticles. The Pd:M ratios in such nanoparticles were found to be 1:1, 1.5:1 and 1:1 in the case of Pd-Zn/C, Pd-Ga/C and Pd-Ag/C, respectively. In the last case, particles of Ag° were also detected. Thereby, based on the TEM and EDX data it can be concluded that the supported active components in the studied samples are represented by both the monometallic and alloyed bimetallic nanoparticles. Average values of the particle size dav as well as particle size distribution calculated from the TEM data are presented in Fig. 2 . The particle size distribution was found to be unimodal in all the cases. As seen, the modifying effect of Zn, Ga and Ag is also appeared in a noticeable decrease of the average particle diameter (more than 20%) and in narrowing of the particle size distribution. It can be supposed that the reduced particles of modifiers play a role of traps for the migrating palladium clusters at elevated temperatures. Formation of relatively small agglomerates of Pd-only and bimetallic nanoparticles at the very beginning stages of calcination facilitates the stabilization of more dispersed particles on the surface of the support. The dispersity of the active components is well known as a key factor affecting the activity of the catalysts in the acetylene hydrogenation, because it belongs to the structure-sensitive reaction. According to the reported data [21,34], the most active in the gas-phase hydrogenation of acetylene traces are Pd particles of about 3–4 nm in size. Along with it, there is no data in the literature related to the optimal size of palladium for the liquid-phase process. To the best of our knowledge, the observed growth of acetylene conversion in the case of the modified catalysts can be explained by an increase of the supported palladium dispersity. Oppositely, low activity of the monometallic Pd/C reference sample (XC2H2 = 30%) can be resulted from larger Pd particles (up to 12 nm) if compare with the bimetallic catalysts containing particles in a range of 1–9 nm (Fig. 2). Difference in activity of the Pd-Ag/C (XC2H2 = 43%) and Pd-Zn/C (XC2H2 = 71%) catalysts is appeared mostly due to formation of a few amount of the bimetallic Pd-Ag sites, which are characterized with the changed palladium electron state [60,69] and its diminished ability towards adsorption of unsaturated compounds. Thereby, it can be supposed that the effect of electron modification is higher for the Pd-Ag/C catalyst than for the Pd-Zn/C catalyst. Moreover, the interaction of Ag with Pd leads to a sharp growth of selectivity in the acetylene hydrogenation (SC2H4 = 80%) for the Pd-Ag/C catalyst if compare with the monometallic reference sample (SC2H4 = 64%). Taking into account mentioned above, it can be concluded that the catalyst modified with silver is characterized with a presence of higher amount of less active PdAg sites exhibiting the highest selectivity in the hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. On the other hand, the possible effects of some other factors should also be considered. In particular, a local blockage of the supported palladium nanoparticles by relatively large particles of metallic silver can possibly takes place [27]. The TEM images have revealed that the bimetallic Pd-Ag/C sample contains a part of supported silver in the form of large metallic particles (up to 9 nm), which are able to cover partly the active sites and decrease the catalyst’s activity. An improved selectivity of the Pd-Zn/C and Pd-Ga/C catalysts with regard to the Pd/C reference sample is believed to be resulted from the formation of the bimetallic structures. At the same time, gallium forms with palladium non-stoichiometric Pd-Ga compounds, as it was demonstrated by EDX. Thereby, it isolates neighboring palladium atoms less efficiently than zinc, and, correspondingly, shows worse selectivity in the target reaction. 3.3 XAS studies The method of X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy was applied in order to obtain information concerning the local structure of the supported metal particles and to confirm the aforementioned suppositions on effects of the palladium modification with other studied metals. The Pd K-edge XANES spectra for the catalysts as well as Ag, Zn and Ga K-edge spectra are presented in Fig. 3 . XANES spectra of Pd, Ga, Ga2O3, Zn, and ZnO reference samples are given for comparison [52]. It is evident that the Pd K-edge XANES spectra of the monometallic Pd/C and bimetallic Pd-Ag/C samples are quite similar to spectrum of palladium foil. However, the oscillation period in the spectrum of Pd/C is higher than that for Pd-Ag/C. Thus, an enlargement of the interatomic distances Pd-Pd in the palladium lattice due to incorporation of silver (more heavy atom) into its structure can be supposed [32]. This supposition correlates well with the TEM data showed the presence of the alloyed Pd-Ag particles in the catalyst. For Zn- and Ga-doped catalysts, the oscillation amplitude of the spectra decreases noticeably in comparison with the monometallic Pd/C and bimetallic Pd-Ag/C catalysts that can be connected with structural disordering. The shape of Ag K-edge XANES spectrum of the Pd-Ag/C sample (Fig. 3b) is evidently different from the same spectra of absorption K-edges of zinc and gallium in the Pd-Zn/C and Pd-Ga/C catalysts, respectively (Fig. 3c,d). The area of absorption jump for the Pd-Zn/C and Pd-Ga/C samples is represented by a sharp intensive peak with rapidly decaying oscillations in near-edge area behind the absorption edge. The interatomic distance between absorbing and backscattering atoms (Å), the Debye-Waller factor σ2 (Å2) and the coordination number were used as fitting parameters during the modelling of EXAFS spectra. The main results of the structural analysis of EXAFS spectra at the K-edges of palladium, zinc, gallium, and silver are shown in Figs. 4 and 5 , and summarized in Table 2 . 3.3.1 Characterization of Pd/C catalyst by EXAFS As it follows from the data presented in Fig. 4 and Table 2, the FT-curve of EXAFS spectrum at the K-edge of Pd for the reference Pd/C sample is simulated by the Pd-Pd distances of 2.72 and 3.85 Å related to the first and second coordination spheres of metallic palladium, respectively. A slight decrease of the interatomic Pd-Pd distances in the case supported palladium (Pd/C sample) with respect to the Pd-Pd distance of 2.75 Å in bulk metallic palladium (Pd foil) with fcc lattice (a = 3.89 Å, CN = 12; ICSD #41517) can be explained by a relatively small size of prepared Pd particles (dav ∼ 7 nm), which can lead to a shrinkage of the crystal lattice due to appearance of the size effect [32]. The presence of metallic palladium in the form of nanosized particles also results in diminishing of the coordination number value (CN = 9.8) in comparison with the bulk metal (CN = 12) that is connected with an increase of the fraction of surface Pd atoms in the case of nanosized systems. Note that no palladium oxide was observed in this sample. 3.3.2 Characterization of Pd-Ag/C sample by EXAFS As mentioned above, according to the TEM results the Pd-Ag/C catalyst contains separate nanoparticles of metallic palladium and silver as well as bimetallic particles of PdxAgy nanoalloy. The feature of this system complicating the analysis of EXAFS spectra is a presence of the two types of atoms – 46Pd and 47Ag – with very similar absorption parameters. Moreover, metallic palladium and silver have identical crystal structure (fcc lattice) with close values of the lattice constant a = 3.89 Å (Pd) and a = 4.09 Å (Ag) and distances between neighboring atoms of 2.75 Å and 2.95 Å for Pd-Pd (ICSD #41517) and Ag-Ag (ICSD #426921), respectively. Identification and analysis of the bimetallic PdxAgy phase are other complicated tasks, because the values of structural parameters of the nanoalloy are located in the middle of the same values for individual metals. Two theoretical models were considered for simulation of Pd K-edge EXAFS spectraof the Pd-Ag/C catalyst. In the first case, the model EXAFS spectrum was obtained similarly to the reference Pd/C sample, and the Pd-Pd(Ag) scattering paths of the PdxAgy phase in the first and the second coordination spheres where taken as a basic. However, this model does not give any differences for the PdxAgy and Pd phases. The modelling results in an average value of the interatomic distance of 2.77 Å with the Debye-Waller factor of 0.009 Å2 that indirectly testifies towards presence of the bimetallic PdxAgy structure. In the second case of simulation, the scattering paths Pd-Pd for metallic palladium and Pd-Pd(Ag) for the bimetallic PdxAgy phase were taken. Application of this approach has allowed us to diminish the R-factor of conformance of experimental and simulated EXAFS spectra (from 4.3% to 3.0%) as well as to decrease the Debye-Waller factor to 0.003 Å2 (Table 2). According to the results of the second model, the Pd-Ag/C sample contains at least 36% of the PdxAgy nanoalloy with the fcc lattice (a = 3.99 Å) and metallic palladium (a = 3.84 Å). The distance between two neighboring Pd atoms of 2.72 Å corresponds to the value of Pd-Pd distance obtained for the monometallic Pd/C. The distance for the Pd-Ag(Pd) scattering path of 2.82 Å occupies an intermediate value between the Pd-Pd distance in the Pd/C sample of 2.72 Å and the theoretical value of the Ag-Ag interatomic distance in metallic silver of 2.95 Å (ICSD #426921). The Ag K-edge EXAFS spectrum of the Pd-Ag/C sample was simulated by coordination spheres of the bimetallic PdxAgy compound with distances between neighboring atoms Ag-Pd(Ag) of 2.81 Å (lattice parameter a = 3.97 Å) and typical for the metallic silver Ag-Ag distances of 2.91 Å (lattice parameter a = 4.12 Å). The Debye-Waller factor σ2 for PdxAgy (0.005 Å2) slightly exceeds σ2 for Ag (0.003 Å2). Therefore, simulation results of the Ag K-edge EXAFS spectrum correspond to the results of simulation of the Pd K-edge EXAFS spectrum of Pd-Ag/C and, thus, confirm presence of metallic palladium, metallic silver and the bimetallic PdxAgy phase. It should be noted that the local enrichment of PdxAgy nanoparticles with silver due to surface segregation or epitaxy is quite possible [67,72,73]. Detailed analysis of stoichiometry of the PdxAgy species being formed in Pd-Ag/C is hindered because of quite small (about 0.1 Å) difference in the interatomic distances of pure Pd and Ag. Estimation of the PdxAgy particle composition was performed in accordance with Vegard’s law using the obtained values of the lattice parameters of palladium (3.84 Å), silver (4.12 Å) and the bimetallic PdxAgy nanoalloy (3.97–3.99 Å) [74]. The linear interpolation between the lattice parameters of metallic palladium and silver has shown that stoichiometry of the nanodisperse PdxAgy phase is close to Pd:Ag = 1:1 (Fig. 6 ). This correlates well with the initial molar ratio used at the preparation as well as with the results of local EDX analysis and literature data for the systems similar in composition [29]. 3.3.3 Characterization of Pd-Zn/C catalyst by EXAFS The Pd K-edge EXAFS spectrum of the Pd-Zn/C catalyst contains peaks simulated by the distances of Pd-O in PdO, Pd-Zn and Pd-Pd in bimetallic PdZn species, and Pd-Pd in metallic palladium (Fig. 4, Table 2). The structure of the formed bimetallic nanodispersed PdZn phase is characterized with an increase of the interatomic distance Pd-Pd in the first coordination sphere from 2.75 Å (for metallic Pd) to 2.90 Å (for PdZn), a presence of the interatomic distance Pd-Zn (2.60–2.64 Å) and a change of the coordination number for Pd-Pd from 12 (for metallic Pd) to 4 and 8 (for Pd-Zn intermetallide) [33,61,66]. Modelling the EXAFS spectra with variation of the quantitative ratio of Pd, PdZn and PdO has shown that for the Pd-Zn/C sample the fraction of Pd atoms included into the PdZn structure (space group P4/mmm) is not less than 40%. Residual palladium is represented by its oxide PdO (near 10%) and metallic palladium with the fcc structure. Analysis of the Zn K-edge absorption of the Pd-Zn/C sample has revealed that Zn partly exists as ZnO oxide with the characteristic distances Zn-O and Zn-Zn. The peak related to the Zn-Zn scattering path of the first coordination sphere of ZnO (2.77 Å) has low intensity. Moreover, the coordination number for Zn-Zn is diminished (CN = 1) in comparison with stoichiometric oxide ZnO (CN = 12; ICSD #190807). It can be supposed that the small values of CN are connected with the small sizes of particles being formed. It is also not excluded that the obtained value of Zn-O distance of 1.96 Å is related not to the bulk zinc oxide but to a thin film of oxidized zinc on the surface of bimetallic PdZn particles formed as a result of their contact with air. Residual part of zinc interacts with palladium forming the bimetallic PdZn compounds characterized with the presence of Zn-Pd and Zn-Zn distances (Table 2). It should be noted that the value of coordination number for the Zn-Pd scattering path (CN = 3.6) in the PdZn structure is slightly lower than that for the ideal PdZn crystal. This indicates that the composition of PdZn phase is deviated from the stoichiometry towards its enrichment with zinc atoms. Besides, a decreased value of the coordination number for palladium can testifies towards the surface segregation of zinc from the bimetallic structure. 3.3.4 Characterization of Pd-Ga/C catalyst by EXAFS The Pd K-edge EXAFS spectrum of the Pd-Ga/C catalyst reminds in shape the spectrum of the Pd-Zn/C sample. It is simulated by the scattering paths of Pd-O, Pd-Ga, and Pd-Pd (Fig. 4, Table 2). According to the TEM and XRD data [44], the Pd-Ga/C catalyst contains the nanosized joint Pd2Ga phase with the orthorhombic lattice (space group Pnma). Hereby, simulation of the EXAFS spectrum of this sample was performed taking into account Pd-Ga scattering paths of PdxGay, Pd-Pd of pure metallic palladium and Pd-O of Pd (II) oxide with variation of their quantitative ratio. As it can be concluded from the modelling results, the main part of palladium (about 70%) is in the metallic state, while near 20% of Pd is represented by its oxide PdO and just around 10% can be assigned to the PdxGay structure. The Debye-Waller factor for metallic palladium has very high value of 0.016 Å2, which indicates the significant distortion of the metal’s crystal lattice. Such disordering of the structure can be explained by both the small sizes of the crystallites and the intercalation of gallium into the palladium lattice. This results in formation of a large amount of structural defects and appearance of a set of close distances that increases the Debye-Waller factor (Table 2) [75]. In particular, the peak simulated by the distance 2.67 Å (Pd-Pd) in metallic palladium can be also attributed to the presence of the Pd-Pd scattering path of 2.80 Å typical for the Pd2Ga phase (COD #8102983) [37]. As it can be seen from the gallium K-edge spectrum (Fig. 5), there are an intensive peak near 1.5 Å and a less intensive peak at ∼2.6 Å, which can be assigned to the distances Ga-O and Ga-M, accordingly. It allows us to suppose a presence of a large amount of Ga2O3 in the Pd-Ga/C sample. The modelling of the spectrum has confirmed this supposition and shown the presence of Ga-O and Ga-Ga(Pd) scattering paths, which are characteristic for oxide of gallium (III) (ICSD #166198) [76]. It should be noted that the low intensity of the second coordination sphere peaks can testify towards the amorphous nature of the oxidized phase. On the other hand, taking into account results of the previous studies [37] and other literature data concerning the high sensitivity of the Pd-Ga intermetallides’ surface towards the oxidation on air [31], a possibility of formation of a thin layer of oxidized gallium on the surface of PdxGay nanoparticles could not be excluded. Since the Ga K-edge EXAFS spectrum is simulated only by the distances of Ga2O3, it can be stated that the amount of the joint Pd-Ga phase in the studied Pd-Ga/C catalyst is quite small. This correlates well with the results of analysis of photoelectron scattering spectra for Ga atoms. It also can be concluded that the coordination number of Pd in PdxGay is not enough for its reliable detection by the Ga K-edge EXAFS. However, in this case the PdxGay species being formed should be enriched with gallium atoms, which is unlikely since it disagrees with the TEM data. 4 Conclusions As it was shown in the present research, carbon-supported palladium catalysts modified with zinc, gallium and silver and prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation exhibit high efficiency in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. The yield of the target product obtained at 55 °C increases in the following order: Pd/C (19%) < Pd-Ag/C (34%) < Pd-Ga/C (42%) < Pd-Zn/C (53%). According to the TEM and XAS data, a rise of hydrogenation selectivity is facilitated by formation of the bimetallic PdZn, PdxGay and PdAg nanoalloys. In the case of the Pd-Zn/C and Pd-Ag/C samples, the selectivity of the process was enhanced due to a significant increase of the distance between neighboring atoms of palladium from 2.72 Å for Pd/C to 2.82–2.89 Å. It is accompanied with a change in geometry of acetylene adsorption (predominantly in π-bonded state) and, correspondingly, with an increase of the target product yield. A growth of acetylene conversion observed for all the modified samples is most evidently stipulated by an increase of amount of the active sites due to higher dispersity of supported metals (more than 20% with regard to the reference monometallic Pd/C catalyst). High activity and selectivity of the Pd-Zn/C catalyst are connected with transformation of approximately half of supported palladium into the bimetallic nanoalloy with composition close to PdZn but different from 1:1 stoichiometry. Oppositely to the Pd-Zn/C system, the Ga-doped catalyst contains just a few of joint palladium-gallium phase with the Pd-Ga distance of 2.57 Å. As it follows from the EXAFS data, only 10% of Pd atoms are transformed into PdxGay thus affecting the selectivity of the process, which is increased on about 3 rel.%. The key factor responsible for the twofold increase of acetylene conversion is seemed to be high dispersity of the supported particles of metallic palladium. The average diameter of Pd particles has diminished in 4 times due to the gallium introduction. On the other hand, some part of the alloyed Pd-Ga particles as well as nanoparticles of metallic palladium can be blocked by a layer of oxidized gallium, which goes out on the surface owing to segregation as it was registered by EXAFS. The highest selectivity in the hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene (80%) was shown by the Pd-Ag/C catalyst. Both XAFS and TEM results testify that more than 36% of Pd atoms interact with silver atoms, thus forming the bimetallic nanoalloy with a composition close to PdAg. A presence of this phase was confirmed by a gradual growth of interatomic distances in a row: Pd (2.72 Å) < PdxAgy (2.82 Å) < Ag (2.91 Å). High selectivity of the Pd-Ag/C catalyst is believed to be connected as with observed increase of interatomic distances due to ‘dilution’ of palladium atoms with silver atoms in the structure of solid solution, as with a change of electronic properties of palladium under the action of introduced silver. It was indirectly confirmed by a low value of the acetylene conversion (43%) over the Pd-Ag/C sample, while for the Pd-Zn/C system with a closed dispersity of palladium the acetylene conversion reaches 71%. Consequently, it can be concluded that the Pd-Ag/C catalyst contains the bimetallic PdAg sites, which are less active but much more selective in the hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. coredata.dc:description: The present work is devoted to the study of doping effects of zinc, gallium and silver on the structure of active sites and catalytic properties of carbon-supported 0.5 wt% Pd catalysts in the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. Carbonaceous graphite-like material Sibunit was used as a support. The reaction was performed in a medium of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone at 55 °C. It was shown that the bimetallic Pd-Zn/C, Pd-Ga/C and Pd-Ag/C catalysts exhibit better activity and selectivity towards target product if compare with the monometallic Pd/C catalyst. The ethylene yield increases in a row as follows: Pd/C (19%) < Pd-Ag/C (34%) < Pd-Ga/C (42%) < Pd-Zn/C (53%). Using X-ray absorption spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy it was found that an improvement of the selectivity is stipulated by the formation of bimetallic PdZn, PdxGay and PdAg nanophases. In the case of Pd-Zn/C and Pd-Ag/C systems, an increased distance between neighboring Pd atoms (2.82–2.89 Å) in relation with monometallic Pd/C, where this distance is 2.72 Å, was observed. The higher activity of modified bimetallic systems is connected with increased number of active sites due to enhanced dispersity of supported palladium doped with second metal.
coredata.dc:title: A study on structural features of bimetallic Pd-M/C (M: Zn, Ga, Ag) catalysts for liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of acetylene
